chapter.title: Terminology Intro
chapter.para:
The desiderata for the design of a controlled healthcare vocabulary was first published in 1989 with seven items and was expanded in 1998 to a list of twelve disederata in the paper by JJ Cimino "Desiderata for Controlled Medical Vocabularies in the Twenty-First Century".
Content
While missing content is expected, formally stated processes for requesting and adding content is required.
Concept orientation
The most granular piece of a terminology must be a concept with a single coherent meaning. Terms associated with a code should represent a single concept.
Ogden and Richards semiotic triangle
Concept permanence
A concepts meaning cannot change and concepts cannot be deleted after they have been released.
Meaningless concept identifiers
Concepts should use unique identifies that do not contain any
Polyhierarchy
Concepts should be allowed to exist in multiple hierarchies if appropriate. For example, Bacterial meningitis is both a subtype of Meningitis and Bacterial infection.
Formal definitions
No residual categories
Multiple granularities
Multiple consistent views
Representing context
Graceful evolution
Recognize redundancy
Duplicate concepts should not exist in the terminology and processes should be in place to both prevent and detect them.
